post_text: If you don’t have a lot of time, but you want to build up your core muscles, doing a plank is the exercise for you! Get into a push-up position, but instead of bending your arms and moving down towards the floor, hold the position with your arms extended. Start off holding the position for 30 seconds, and add an additional 10 seconds every day. See how long you can go for – it’s definitely not easy! This is one of the most challenging exercises, but it’s also one of the best for your core.

post_text: Sock Wars! 6th-8th graders, grab 10-20 socks rolled into balls. Divide into two teams and divide the room into two equal halves. Place the socks in a line in the middle of the room (you could use masking take to mark this). When the timer starts, players try to get as many socks onto the other side of the room before the time is up. Team members must stay on their side of the room and toss the socks over to the other side. When the time beeps, all players must stop so the socks can be counted!

Make a homemade lava lamp! Here is a colorful activity for fifth graders to do at home this spring break.

Supplies:
-Empty soda or water bottle
-Cooking oil
-Water
-Food coloring
-Alka-Seltzer tablets

3. Add a couple of drops of food coloring

What better way to end the week, than with a frozen treat that’s sweet to eat! Make some frozen yogurt covered fruit.

Things you'll need:
-Any amount of any fresh fruit (blueberries, strawberries, bananas, etc)
-Greek yogurt or yogurt of any flavor
-A toothpick

Directions:
1. Start by washing and draining your fruit to make sure it's clean
2. Using a toothpick, dip your desired fruit into your yogurt and coat the fruit with your yogurt
3. Place all fruit dipped in yogurt onto a plate or baking sheet.
4. Once all fruit is on the plate/baking sheet, put it in the freezer for at least an hour
5. After an hour you can eat and enjoy!

Read the original recipe here: https://www.familyfreshmeals.com/2013/05/frozen-yogurt-covered-blueberries.html

Can’t get outside to play basketball? No worries! A few pairs of socks and a laundry basket is a great activity for our sixth-eighth graders to play some indoor basketball. Use pairs of socks as basketballs and a laundry basket as the hoop. Shots from different distances can have different point values. The first player to a determined number of points wins!

Another variation: each player tosses the basketball, and if they make a basket they take one step back. Repeat. Whoever steps the farthest back without missing wins.
